Content.Question:
Quotation #1On ðaes siwenigean eagum beoð ða aepplas hale, ac ða braewas greatigað,..oððaet sio scearpnes bið gewird ðaes aepples.
King Aelfred, Pastoral Care
895

Quotation #2Ðurh ðone aepl ðaes eagan mon maeg geseon.
King Aelfred, Pastoral Care
895

Quotation #3La prunele, the appel of the eye.
W. de Biblesworth,
1299

Quotation #4The Appyll of ye ee, pupilla.
, Catholicon Anglicum
1475

Quotation #5We see our owne eies shine within the apples of our neighbours eies.
T. Bowes, French Acad.
1586

Quotation #6The dart did undergore His eye-lid, by his eye's dear roots, & out the apple fell.
G. Chapman, Iliad
1600

Quotation #7None have their eyes all of one color, for the bal or apple in the midst is ordinarily of another color than the white about.
P. Holland, Hist. World
1601

Quotation #8Having carefully observ'd the Eyes of several Fishes..I found that the..Pupil or Apple of the Eye, was very flat, like those in Human Creatures.
, Philos. Trans. 1704–05
1705

Quotation #9He cut asunder the Apple of the eye in several animals.
, Chambers's Cycl.
1753

Quotation #10Dull people turn up..the apples of their eyes on beholding Prose by a Poet.
, Blackwood's Edinb. Mag.
1827

Quotation #11Large dark blue sparkling eye..with much white, of a bluish shade, visible under the apple.
, Anthropol. Rev.
1870

Quotation #12The eye was also considered so as to elucidate the origin and application of such terms as bulb, apple, iris, pupil, cataract.
, Lancet
1912

Quotation #13Just you take a look at Jimmy here's eye..two circles there be, one for range and t'other for intelligence, and locked up in the apple, sir.
H. Williamson, Golden Virgin
1957

Quotation #14At this time the pupil of the eye was thought to be a solid object and was known as the apple because it was spherical.
, People
2004
Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Sense #1
More fully apple of the eye. The pupil of the eye, originally thought to be a solid, spherical body. Occasionally also: the iris and pupil, or the whole eyeball. Now historical.
First use: King Alfred
Part of speech: NN
895 -
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
Quotation #1Spere, aepples.
, Cleopatra Gloss.
935

Quotation #2Worpað hine deofol on domdaege, draca egeslice, bismorlice, of blacere liðran irenum aplum.
, Metrical Dialogue of Solomon & Saturn
1045

Quotation #3He was wont to holden a round appell of gold in his hond.
, Mandeville's Trav.
1424

Quotation #4Ȝe most forsake of golde ȝowre appil rounde Sceptre and swerde.
J. Lydgate, Daunce Machabree
1430

Quotation #5To make ye apple of the chieck ruddy.
P. Morwyng, Treasure of Euonymus
1559

Quotation #6The knight kneeleth..with his naked sworde vnder his arme, the whiche beeing made of Iasper sprinkled with Uermilion spots, seemeth to be al bloudy, & hee presenteth an apple of the same stone to the Princesse.
H. Wotton, Courtlie Controuersie
1578

Quotation #7Hold a round ball or hollow apple of glasse.
P. Holland, Hist. World
1601

Quotation #8You that carried Summer in your lips..That in the Apples of your cheeks did wear A fertile Autumn now no fruit can bear?
R. Heath, Clarastella
1650

Quotation #9Shrugging up her Shoulders, to shew the tempting Apples of her white Breasts.
J. S., City & Country Recreation
1705

Quotation #10The Vane on the Top of the Steeple is a Piece of fine Work..at the Extremity is a large gilded Apple or Globe.
W. Guthrie, Trav.
1743

Quotation #11A Venus, with the Wand or Hasta pura in one Hand, and the Golden Apple or Globe in the other.
W. Cooke, Medallic Hist. Imperial Rome
1781

Quotation #12He press'd His hand upon the apples of my breast.
‘Philocomus’, Love Feast
1865

Quotation #13Of double-faced Canton flannel, finished with fringe and floss apples.
, N.Y. Art Interchange
1881

Quotation #14Andy picked up his two grenades... The apples felt strangely heavy in his hands.
M. Hargrove, Girl he left Behind
1956

Quotation #15Thereafter the ‘imperial apple’ became an important emblem of the royal power invested in the monarch.
, Encycl. Brit. Macropaedia
1974

Quotation #16A peasant blouse that showed the top of those lovely little apples.
C. W. Smith, Country Music
1975

Quotation #17Apply powder blush directly to the apple of the cheek.
, Red
2004
Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Sense #2
Any of various things resembling an apple in form or colour; spec. = pome n.1 2.
First use: Cleopatra Glossary
Part of speech: NN
935 -
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:

935

Quotation #2Genim brembelaeppel & elehtran & pollegian, gecnua.
, Bald's Leechbk.
950

, Old Eng. Hexateuch: Num.
1025

Quotation #4Þe Applene weren ripe inouȝ, riȝt ase it heruest were.
, St. Brendan
1300

Quotation #5Quane here apples ripe ben, fier-isles man mai ðor-inne sen.
, Gen. & Exod.
1324

Quotation #6Alle maner appul þat is closed in an harde skyn, rynde or schale is ycleped nux.
J. Trevisa, De Proprietatibus Rerum
1397

1399

Quotation #8Take þe appullis of sypressus and ete hem or þe pouder of þe applys dryed.

Quotation #9Venemous apples wherwith they poyson theyr arrowes.

1555

1601

Quotation #12The fruite or Apples of Palme-trees.
E. Topsell, Hist. Foure-footed Beastes
1607

Quotation #13The other trees gave no fruit; an uselesse apple from the Oak, or little berries from the Laurel and the Myrtle.
Bp. J. Taylor, Worthy Communicant
1660

Quotation #14The apples call'd pompions by the Dutch,..grow scarce anywhere else in the Indies but in the Isle of Great Java.
, Voy. E.-Indies
1704

Quotation #15It is remarkable for producing great quantities of that delicious fruit we called apples.
J. Cook, Voy. Pacific
1784

Quotation #16The Custard-apples, Sweetsops, and Soursops, of the East and West Indies, are furnished by various species of Anona.
J. H. Balfour, Man. Bot.
1849

Quotation #17Then came a course of fruits grown upon the place: luscious ‘Ripley’ Pine Apples and Star Apples (the latter..when cut across, displayed the seed chambers arranged in the exact form of a star).
, Harper's Mag.
1858

Quotation #18It is a much-branched small tree or shrub, reaching a height of 6 meters, and is also known as the Punic apple.
N. L. Britton, N. Amer. Trees
1908

Quotation #19A section of the ‘potato apple’ is like that of the tomato.
, Times Educ. Suppl.
1930

Quotation #20I had inadvertently cut the branch of an overhanging manzanillo tree, whose apples are poison to humans.
, Smithsonian
2005
Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Sense #3
Frequently with distinguishing word: any of various fruits (and vegetables), esp. those thought to resemble the apple (sense 1) in some way; any of the plants producing such a fruit (or vegetable).
First use: Cleopatra Glossary
Part of speech: NN
935 -

Content.Question:
Quotation #1Se godcunda anwald gefrioðode his deorlingas under fiðra sceate, & hi scilde swa geornlice swa man deð þone aeppel on his eagan.
King Aelfred, De Consol. Philos.
950

Quotation #2Geheald me, Drihten, and beorh me, swa swa man byrhð þam aeplum on his eagum mid his braewum.
King Aelfred, Psalms
1050

Quotation #3Kepe me..as þe appel of þyn eȝe.
, Psalter
1350

Quotation #4Als appel ofe eghe yheme þou me.
, Psalter
1399

Quotation #5If you touche him in the Indies, you touche the apple of his eye.
R. Hakluyt, Disc. Western Planting
1584

Quotation #6that shall nourish no blood but your owne, tender your reputation as the apple of her eye, & honour euen your verie footsteps.
E. Sharpham, Cupids Whirligig
1607

Quotation #7He can't live without you. You're the Apple of his Eye, the Joy of his Heart, the Lamp of his Life.
J. Bancroft, Henry II
1693

Quotation #8His daughter beautiful and young..The perfect picture of her mother's youth, His age's hope, the apple of his eye.
M. Bruce, Poems
1766

Quotation #9Poor Richard was to me as an eldest son, the apple of my eye.
W. Scott, Old Mortality
1816

Quotation #10Col. Gildersleeve has lost his valuable setter dog Don, which animal was the apple of his eye.
, Spirit of Times
1877

Quotation #11He was a master of his profession, and his journal was to him as the apple of his eye.
, Harper's Mag.
1884

Quotation #12Live and die The apple, nay the onion, of his eye?
R. Campbell, Poems
1930

Quotation #13He parked his 1932 Mercedes-Benz (he called it the apple of his eye) outside A Block.
R. Mistry, Tales from Firozsha Baag
1987

Quotation #14Errol was the apple of my grandmother's eye because he was her eldest.
P. Jooste, Dance with Poor Man's Daughter
1998
Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Sense #4
More fully apple of the eye. figurative and in extended use. Originally: the type of something precious. In later use chiefly the apple of a person's eye: the particular object of a person's affection or regard; a greatly cherished person or occasionally thing.
First use: King Alfred
Part of speech: NN
950 -
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Quotation #1Him mon on fruman þa mettas gife..swa swa beoþ aeppla, nales to swete ealles ac surmelsce, & peran & persucas.

Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Sense #5
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Content.Question:
Quotation #1Aeppel unsaelga, þone hire aer forbead drihtna drihten, deaðbeames ofet.
, Genesis B
1000

Quotation #2Eue bi heold oðe for boden appel.
, Ancrene Riwle
1225

Quotation #3How adam brake goddis comandement of the appil.
, Cursor Mundi
1399

, Bk. Knight of La Tour Landry

, St. Erkenwald
1499

Quotation #6These maner of people sell paradise for an apple, with Adam and Eue.

1526

Quotation #7Was it such a sinne for Adam to eate a forbidden Apple? Yes, the greatnes is remonstrable in the euent.
T. Adams, Happines of Church
1618

Quotation #8Him by fraud I have seduc'd From his Creator..with an Apple.
J. Milton, Paradise Lost
1667

J. J. Hornyold, Real Princ. Catholicks
1749

Quotation #10The Apple had done but little for me If Eve had not done the rest.
R. Southey, All for Love
1829

Quotation #11You see, Eva, since Adam took the apple from Eve men have obeyed women nem. con.
H. B. Stowe, My Wife & I
1871

Quotation #12Since man ate the apple..the human emotions are like a wedded wife.
D. H. Lawrence, Phoenix
1924

Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Sense #6
According to post-biblical Christian tradition: the fruit of the tree of knowledge of good and evil eaten by Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden in defiance of God's commandment; the forbidden fruit. Also used allusively.
First use: Genesis B
Part of speech: NN
1000 -

Content.Question:
Quotation #1Yn the calendars of Ianuar' Thu sclatt treys both set & rere To graffy ther yn appyl & pere.
, Treat. Gardening
1499

Quotation #2Takyng a branche of a Beeche a foote thicke: and when they haue cutte it and bored it, they set in it the branches of the best Peare or Apple that they can geat.
B. Googe, Foure Bks. Husbandry
1577

Quotation #3Oakes, Beeches, Chesnuts,..&c. last longer than Apples, Peares, Plums, &c.
F. Bacon, Sylua Syluarum
1626

Quotation #4Graft..all kinds of Apples together, and also on Crabstocks.
R. Austen, Treat. Fruit-trees
1653

Quotation #5You may also continue to prune Pears, Apples, and Plums until the middle or latter end of the next month.
P. Miller, Gardeners Kalendar
1731

Quotation #6Fruit Trees thrive very well here, Apples Pears, Peaches, Plumbs Nectrans, Cherries Rasberries, & Several other fine Fruit.
W. Bartram, Trav. Georgia & Florida
1774

Quotation #7The apple, though cultivated,..seems to be an exotic in southern Louisiana.
W. Darby, Geogr. Descr. Louisiana
1816

Quotation #8The pear may be budded on the thorn, the mountain ash, or the apple, but the practice is not to be recommended.
J. J. Black, Cultiv. Peach & Pear
1887

Quotation #9A friend of mine..recently bought a tract of land in Georgia, with a view to planting apples.
, Times
1907

Quotation #10The Wild Apple has not the pyramidal form of the Wild Pear.
E. Step, Wayside & Woodland Trees
1940

Quotation #11In 1883 Allen planted a mixture of Northern Spy, Baldwin and Rhode Island Greening apples.

Quotation #12Some temperate trees (like apples and horse chestnuts) are pollinated by animals.

Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Sense #7
Any tree of the genus Malus (family Rosaceae); esp. any of the numerous varieties cultivated for their fruit, probably of hybrid origin and usually classified as M. domestica, having alternate serrated leaves and white blossom appearing in the spring, followed by fruit in late summer or autumn. Cf. apple tree n.
First use: Treat. Gardening
Part of speech: NN
1499 -
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
Quotation #1What so euer fruite is to be eaten soft without, and hard within, is an Apple, and the contrary a Nut.
B. Googe, Foure Bks. Husbandry
1577

Quotation #2An Apple, Pomum, is generally understood to be any fleshy Vessel containing more Seeds than one.
J. Martyn, 1st Lect. Bot.
1729

Quotation #3Pomum or apple, which is a fleshy or pulpy kind of pericarpium: it contains in the middle a membraneous capsule..in which the seeds reside.
R. Saumarez, New Syst. Physiol.
1799
Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Sense #8
Botany. Any fruit having the structure of the apple; a pome. Obsolete.
First use: Barnabe Googe
Part of speech: NN
1577 - 1799
This sense is obsolete

Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Content.Question:

1918

Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

rotten (also bad) apple: a negative or corrupting influence on others; a troublesome or despicable person; cf. phrases 2.

Part of speech: NN
1887 -

Content.Question:

1943

Quotation #2How's it going, Wally? Everything apples?
T. A. G. Hungerford, Ridge & River
1952

Quotation #3She felt their faint movements of relief and surprise. ‘Well,’ said Dixon, ‘that'd be a break. That'd be apples, that would.’
R. Stow, To Islands
1958

Quotation #4Don't cry, Pru. Yuh go and see old Len Ramsbottom and betcha everything'll be apples.
R. H. Morrieson, Scarecrow
1963

, Sydney Morning Herald
1975

Quotation #6She's apples. Now you just lie back an' take it easy.
R. Beilby, Gunner
1977

Quotation #7Apples & Rice, nice. Generally shortened to the first element when describing something that is nice, e.g. ‘She's apples’. But used in full when used to describe something that isn't, e.g., ‘Oh, that's very apples and rice. I'm out of work and you're pregnant again.’
R. Puxley, Cockney Rabbit
1992

Quotation #8Well, she's not much of a motor, but with a spray job and a new radiator she'll be apples!
, Fast Forward
1994
Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Sense #19
slang (chiefly Australian and New Zealand). Used to indicate a state of affairs regarded as good or satisfactory (or occasionally ironic the reverse). Chiefly in she's (also it's) apples and variants: everything is all right; things will be fine (see she pron.1 2a(e)).
First use: J. Binning
Part of speech: NN
1943 -

The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Content.Question:
Quotation #1For all the sort of them during the Summer throughout, never rest and give over, but either they floure, or they apple, or els be readie to bring foorth fruit.

1750

Content.Answer:
intransitive. Of vegetables, flower buds, and esp. (in later use) root crops: to swell into a globular shape; to become shaped like an apple.

Sense #1
intransitive. Of vegetables, flower buds, and esp. (in later use) root crops: to swell into a globular shape; to become shaped like an apple.
First use: Philemon Holland
Part of speech: VB
1601 -
This is the main current sense

intransitive. Of vegetables, flower buds, and esp. (in later use) root crops: to swell into a globular shape; to become shaped like an apple.

Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

1994

Quotation #4I never saw money to do good things to Indians, it turns them into ‘Apples’—red on the outside, white in the middle.
, Adrenalin
2001
Content.Answer:
The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.

Sense #20
U.S. slang (derogatory). In North American Indian usage: a North American Indian regarded as espousing or adopting the values of white society or culture (see quot. 2001). Cf. Oreo n.1 2.
First use: Lawton (Okla.) Constit.
Part of speech: NN
1970 -
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
Quotation #1For all the sort of them during the Summer throughout, never rest and give over, but either they floure, or they apple, or els be readie to bring foorth fruit.
P. Holland, Hist. World
1601

Quotation #2To Pome or Apple, is said of the Heads of Artichokes when they grow round, and full shaped as an Apple. It is said also of Lettuce, &c.
J. Evelyn, Compl. Gard'ner
1693

Quotation #3Unless the Soil has some mixture of Sand the Turnips do not apple, as they call it: that is, do not bottom well.
J. Morton, Nat. Hist. Northants.
1712

Quotation #4The Turneps grew 'till Christmas or longer, and appled well in gravelly or stony Grounds, because their Roots can't here enter so deep.
W. Ellis, Mod. Husbandman
1750

Quotation #5The cabbage turnep is of two kinds; one apples above ground, and the other in it.
C. Marshall, Introd. Knowl. & Pract. Gardening
1798

Quotation #6Apple, to bottom at the roots. Turnips apple well, when the roots well, and assume a bulbous form.
A. E. Baker, Gloss. Northants. Words
1854

Quotation #7The fine-leaved turnips that have escaped the fly, but have still to ‘apple’.
P. H. Emerson, Birds, Beasts, & Fishes Norfolk Broadland
1895

Quotation #8Potatoes and onions are said to apple when they develop properly. A dialect use.
E. Gepp, Essex Dial. Dict.
1923

Quotation #9Me taters be n't applin' like they ed ough'ter.
M. Carbery, Herts. Heritage
1948

Quotation #10Them blubs (bulbs) what we put awaay int' spring's gone an' appled nicely.
J. M. Sims-Kimbrey, Wodds & Doggerybaw: Lincs. Dial. Dict.
1995
Content.Answer:
intransitive. Of vegetables, flower buds, and esp. (in later use) root crops: to swell into a globular shape; to become shaped like an apple.

Sense #1
intransitive. Of vegetables, flower buds, and esp. (in later use) root crops: to swell into a globular shape; to become shaped like an apple.
First use: Philemon Holland
Part of speech: VB
1601 -
This is the main current sense
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
Quotation #1The poor people supply themselves with very good fuel by gathering the fir-apples and rotten wood; you will sometimes see twenty children in my plantations appleing, as they call it.
A. Young, Gen. View Agric. County Lincoln
1799

Quotation #2Going out appling is going out into the woods to collect fir cones for burning.
J. M. Sims-Kimbrey, Wodds & Doggerybaw: Lincs. Dial. Dict.
1995
Content.Answer:
intransitive. Of vegetables, flower buds, and esp. (in later use) root crops: to swell into a globular shape; to become shaped like an apple.

Sense #2
intransitive. To gather fir cones (see fir-apple n. at fir n. compounds 2). rare.
First use: Arthur Young
Part of speech: VB
1799 -
